file_name: Wang 等 - 2024 - Smart Mobility Digital Twin Based Automated Vehicle Navigation System A Proof of Concept.pdf

structured_info.title_cn: 基于智能移动数字孪生的自动车辆导航系统：概念验证
structured_info.title_en: Smart Mobility Digital Twin Based Automated Vehicle Navigation System: A Proof of Concept
structured_info.abstract: Digital twins (DTs) have driven major advancements across various industrial domains over the past two decades. With the rapid advancements in autonomous driving and vehicle-to-everything (V2X) technologies, integrating DTs into vehicular platforms is anticipated to further revolutionize smart mobility systems. In this paper, a new smart mobility DT (SMDT) platform is proposed for the control of connected and automated vehicles (CAVs) over next-generation wireless networks. In particular, the proposed platform enables cloud services to leverage the abilities of DTs to promote the autonomous driving experience. To enhance traffic efficiency and road safety measures, a novel navigation system that exploits available DT information is designed. The SMDT platform and navigation system are implemented with state-of-the-art products, e.g., CAVs and roadside units (RSUs), and emerging technologies, e.g., cloud and cellular V2X (C-V2X). In addition, proof-of-concept (PoC) experiments are conducted to validate system performance. The performance of SMDT is evaluated from two standpoints: (i) the rewards of the proposed navigation system on traffic efficiency and safety and, (ii) the latency and reliability of the SMDT platform. Our experimental results using SUMO-based large-scale traffic simulations show that the proposed SMDT can reduce the average travel time and the blocking probability due to unexpected traffic incidents. Furthermore, the results record a peak overall latency for DT modeling and route planning services to be 155.15 ms and 810.59 ms, respectively, which validates that our proposed design aligns with the 3GPP requirements for emerging V2X use cases and fulfills the targets of the proposed design.
structured_info.methodology: Design and implementation of a cloud-based Smart Mobility Digital Twin (SMDT) platform integrating roadside units (RSUs) and connected automated vehicles (CAVs) with LiDAR sensing, V2X communication, and cloud-edge computing. Methods include a novel event-triggered navigation algorithm for CAVs, proof-of-concept field trials for real-world validation, and large-scale traffic simulations using SUMO for performance evaluation.
structured_info.conclusion: The SMDT platform effectively enhances traffic efficiency and safety by reducing average travel time and blocking probability in simulations. Latency measurements (155.15 ms for DT modeling, 810.59 ms for route planning) meet 3GPP requirements for V2X use cases. Future work should expand the platform city-wide and integrate predictive algorithms.

analysis.Overview: The paper proposes a Smart Mobility Digital Twin (SMDT) platform for cloud-based control of connected and automated vehicles (CAVs), featuring a navigation system that uses real-time traffic data to improve efficiency and safety. Research focuses on integrating digital twins with V2X communications, cloud-edge computing, and autonomous driving.
Background_and_Motivation: Digital twins (DTs) have advanced industrial sectors but lack real-world validation in smart mobility; broader challenges include overcoming CAV limitations like restricted sensing views and computing resources.

Motivation stems from the need to validate DT advantages in end-to-end smart mobility systems and solve specific problems like traffic congestion and accident avoidance through real-time DT-enabled navigation.

Authors argue necessity by highlighting the 20% automotive revenue share in the growing DT market (USD 11.12 billion in 2022) and urgency from unaddressed gaps in practical DT applications for autonomous driving.

The specific problem of enhancing CAV navigation is linked to broader societal challenges of traffic safety and efficiency, establishing significance through market impact and potential for revolutionary mobility systems.
Contributes to intelligent transportation systems, autonomous driving, wireless communications, and interdisciplinary fields like cloud-edge computing and V2X networks.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts: (1) Smart Mobility Digital Twin (SMDT) – a cloud-based platform creating real-time digital models of traffic environments; (2) CAV Navigation System – an event-triggered routing service using DT data; (3) Event-Triggered Mechanism – detects incidents like pedestrian gatherings or accidents to dynamically reroute vehicles.

Logical relationships: SMDT integrates sensing and communication to model traffic; this feeds the navigation system, which uses the event-triggered mechanism to optimize routes, forming a feedback loop between physical and digital worlds.

Key assumptions: Reliable V2X communication exists, sensor data (e.g., LiDAR from RSUs/CAVs) is accurate and sufficient for DT modeling, and cloud-edge computing can handle real-time processing delays.
Contribution type: Advances practical knowledge through a novel system architecture and implementation, offering a foundational framework for DT applications in autonomous driving.
Methodology: Core methods: Cloud-edge computing for data processing; LiDAR-based object detection and tracking; V2X communication for data sharing; Dijkstra algorithm for route optimization; SUMO simulations for large-scale validation.
Novelty lies in the integrated SMDT platform design; applicability is demonstrated via real-world PoC; rationality is supported by aligning latency with 3GPP standards.

Data sources: LiDAR sensors on RSUs and CAVs for real-time point clouds, supplemented by SUMO-generated traffic data. Preprocessing includes object detection (CenterPoint framework) and tracking. Representativeness is evaluated through field trials and simulations covering urban scenarios.

Experimental design includes PoC field trials for functional validation and SUMO simulations for performance metrics; evaluation metrics (latency, travel time, blocking probability) are rigorous and adequate, assessed against 3GPP KPIs.
Follows the parallel intelligence paradigm, emphasizing bidirectional physical-cyber integration; this shapes the research by prioritizing real-time feedback and control in autonomous systems.
Results: Key results: SUMO simulations show 16.7% CAV penetration reduces average travel time and event encounters; PoC experiments confirm successful rerouting around incidents; peak latencies are 155.15 ms (DT modeling) and 810.59 ms (route planning), meeting 3GPP targets.

Significance: Demonstrates practical feasibility for improving traffic efficiency and safety. Reliability is high (99.53% packet delivery rate); stability is evidenced by consistent latency performance across experiments.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Overall argument structure: Introduces DT potential, identifies gaps, proposes SMDT platform and navigation system, details implementation, validates via PoC/simulations, and concludes with implications.

Key steps: (1) Background on DT benefits; (2) Problem statement of unvalidated real-world applications; (3) SMDT architecture design; (4) Navigation system as use case; (5) Implementation and validation; (6) Results confirming efficiency/safety improvements.

Strengths: Clear progression from theory to practice with experimental validation. Weaknesses: Limited discussion of cybersecurity risks. Authors address potential rebuttals (e.g., scalability concerns) by suggesting city-wide expansion in future work.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths: Comprehensive real-world implementation with hardware/software integration; innovative event-triggered navigation reducing travel time; validated latency compliance with standards.
Methodology limitations: Reliance on stable V2X communication; limited sensor coverage in test field; scalability untested for dense urban environments.
Theoretical paradigm constraints: Focus on centralized cloud control may limit adaptability to decentralized scenarios, affecting generalizability of conclusions.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Role: Positions as a pioneering practical validation of DTs in autonomous driving, bridging theoretical research and real-world applications in transportation discourse.
Terminology: Technical terms like 'CAV', 'V2X', and 'cloud-edge computing'; formal tone; rhetorical strategies include emphasizing market data for urgency and experimental results for credibility.

Authority building: Cites 3GPP standards and prior works (e.g., CenterPoint framework) to justify methods; motivations include establishing feasibility through empirical evidence and addressing cited gaps.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Main conclusions: The SMDT platform enables efficient CAV navigation via real-time DT modeling, reducing travel time and enhancing safety while meeting latency requirements.
Future insights: Expand to city-scale deployments; integrate predictive algorithms for traffic forecasting; enhance robustness with advanced sensor fusion and cybersecurity measures.
